entry.title: Gamification
entry.summary: Defines gamification, contrasts key definitions, outlines design element levels, and critiques simplistic approaches, advocating intrinsically motivating, user-centred, theory-informed design.
entry.content:
Gamification grew from a mix of interacting trends and traditions in interaction design and games. Gamification describes those features of an interactive system that aim to motivate and engage end-users through the use of game elements and mechanics.

The two common definitions of gamification in academic research are by Deterding et al. and Huotari and Hamari. The former defines gamification as “use of game design elements in non-game contexts”, whereas the latter defines gamification as a “process of enhancing a service with affordances for gameful experiences in order to support user’s overall value creation.”

The key differences are that Deterding et al.’s definition explains how to operationalise gamification and prioritises the game design elements, while Huotari and Hamari describe a broader process centred on the user experience.

Gamification can be viewed as enriching artefacts with game-design elements to positively influence users. Deterding et al. outline levels of game design elements ranging from interface elements (e.g., badges, leaderboards) to design patterns/mechanics (e.g., time constraints, limited resources), principles/heuristics (e.g., clear goals), models (e.g., MDA), and methods (e.g., playtesting).

Here is the table from the original HTML preserved in raw format:

Level Examples
Interface elements Badges, leaderboards
Design patterns/mechanics Time constraints, limited resources
Principles/heuristics Clear goals
Models MDA (Mechanics-Dynamics-Aesthetics)
Methods Playtesting

Common features like points, badges and leaderboards alone are insufficient to create gameful experiences; they mainly provide interaction and feedback. Effective gamification should aim at intrinsic motivation through autonomy, mastery and purpose, and be grounded in users’ needs, social styles, expertise and engagement.

Designing and adjusting gamified services is complex and extends beyond simple point systems. Although widely applied in education/training, sustainability and healthcare/wellness, research often lacks robust theory, validated constructs, appropriate measurement, and consideration of individual differences. More rigorous quantitative and qualitative studies are needed.
